Award.AwardTitle: EARS: A TV Whitespace Communication System for Connected Vehicles

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project is focused on designing a holistic communication stack that leverages TV whitespaces for enabling "connected vehicles" and their many advantages in ushering smarter and safer transportation services. The combination of low cost of the unlicensed TV whitespace spectrum and its longer communication ranges matches the needs of vehicular connectivity quite well. Yet realizing TV whitespace communications faces unique constraints and challenges including, e.g., protecting primary incumbents, scanning through many channel configurations subject to spatial-temporal variations, dealing with asymmetric uplink/downlink transmit power constraints due to FCC regulations concerning mobile and static nodes. The proposed research addresses these challenges through a range of techniques. It augments spectrum sensing techniques from sensors distributed across moving vehicles to enhance the accuracy of spectrum databases. It employs innovative PHY and MAC layer techniques including variable spreading codes, MIMO and directional antennas, complemented with network/transport layer protocols that adapt to uplink/downlink asymmetry. These research tasks integrate machine learning techniques to explore the predictable mobility and other unique advantages of the vehicular whitespace network.

This project is developing a new communication technology for improved and robust wide-area connectivity for vehicles. All developed techniques are expected to be deployed in a practical setting on a realistic vehicular testbed in Madison, WI. The research work engages collaboration with many industry partners and is expected to influence regulatory and standardization bodies. The researchers are also making educational impact through public lectures, developing new curriculum, and motivating women and minorities in future STEM careers through appropriate PI engagement at high school and undergraduate levels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project has developed numerous techniques to enable TV whitespace based communication for vehicular systems. The following are some of the key examples.

(a) A dual radio system, called Scout, that allows TV whitespace technology to be combined with other complementary technologies, to improve connectivity solutions. It uses an estimation system by which a front radio in a vehicle can provide better guide a back radio to operate more efficiently and drive more throughput across the wireless channel.

(b) Techniques to understand wireless useage and coverage across a city-scale using mobile sensors deployed on various vehicles. The data gathered from such sensors have been publicly shared. Further, techniques have been developed to validate whether the spectrum is being used efficiently. Other mechanisms allow to detect and identify unexpected transmitters in the region of interest. 

(c) Through extensive measurements on a programmable TV-whitespace software-radio testbed, we found that the uplink-downlink power asymmetry of TV-whitespace networks not only causes severe uplink blackouts but also poses significant link coexistence problems. We have designed and implemented an adaptive DSSS mechanism that strategically configures the spreading code, so as to boost uplink coverage under the power constraint. Our experiments show that the adaptive DSS can eliminate link asymmetry for realistic application layer traffic.

(d) We have designed and implemented CLAW, the first work to quantitatively model the relation between LTE’s resource utilization and the PHY-layer statistics on commodity cellphones. The model can be adapted by a broader range of wireless protocols, including not only web loading, but also video streaming, background traffic scheduling, etc. CLAW is also the first to achieve zero-overhead bottleneck detection and explicit loss differentiation over LTE. The CLAW design relies on PHY information, but entails no PHY-layer modification and is readily deployable on current LTE devices.

(e) We proposed and implemented a sensing-assisted directional basestation deployment solution, which marks the first step towards light-weight wireless network planning. Basestation deployment is an age-old problem, and still heavily relies on brute-force war-driving as a solution. Our work can significantly simplify the procedure, by allowing the radios to reconstruct the environment profile, and then predict the site-specific signal strength distribution.

(f) We have designed and implemented POI360, the first portable interactive 360◦ video telephony system customized for existing LTE cellular network infrastructure. POI360 dynamically tunes the compression strategy to fit the varying cellular network conditions. POI360’s awareness of cellular link statistics enables prompt adaptation to facilitate smooth 360◦ video telephony. POI360 will manifest its impact not only as a new application (interactive virtual reality), but also as a new design principle to drive new interactive applications over bandwidth-limited infrastructure networks.
